div.p:
Letter not found. The text given here is from 'A dangerous poison plant', Kerang times, 19 November 1895, p. [2] (B95.11.05). It is introduced by:
Mr St. Eloy D'Alton, who is ever on the alert for something new in botany, says the Nhill Mail, surmising that a species which came under his observation the other day was of a poisonous nature, sent a specimen of it to Baron Von Mueller. The plant, which was discovered in a garden near Lemon Spring, about five miles from Mortat, is something like a lily, and attains to a height of about 18 inches. It has grassy leaves like an onion, and bears a flower of a color between orange and red. The plant is said to be spreading near Melbourne. Baron von Mueller in a letter to Mr D'Alton, writes of it as follows :—‘.
Both the Kerang times and Nhill mail were published semi-weekly, and the letter is dated to early November on the assumption that D'Alton reported it to the Nhill mail soon after it was received.
The irradeceous
Typesetter's error for iridaceous? plant sent by you is as you surmised,
D'Alton's letter not found.
I toyed with making an entry in the items not found part of M pubs, but decided as we will be able to find it, I will wait until that is done before emending the file. If nothing else turns up in the meantime, it is likely to be allocated B95.11.08, and cross referenced to the other two assuming my added dating statement ¶ to fn 1 is correct, but I would not be surprised if the letter in the Nhill Times was in late October, in which case we would have to redate the letter, M does not seem to have kept the specimen, as it is not on AVH for MEL, under that name or its current name of
Moraea
miniata
(unless it is the
Moraea ochroleuca, among the 20 specimens recorded from D'Alton 1895, MEL
2262918. It would be worth a look to see what M identified this one as when he got it.
a Homeria — the Homeria lineata from South Africa, in its narrow-leaved form. Like the few other Homerias this one also is highly poisonous, and in its native localities cases of death of human beings have occurred from eating the bulbs. In our colony cattle have perished from browsing on this plant. It should be discarded in gardens within winterless zones everywhere now that attention has been directed to this highly pernicious plant, and it should be uprooted wherever it got away from gardens, and be burnt at once. The greatest danger of this dreadful bulbous plant establishing itself and spreading on our rural lands consists in its producing copious broods of bulbilles, not only from the roots, but also from the axils of the leaves, so that the Homerias more largely multiply than any bulbous plant among the hundreds of sorts.
